quickFacts.name: Designation

data.title: North Rim Campground Laundry and Showers
data.listingDescription: The North Rim is CLOSED for the remainder of the 2025 season because of damage and losses caused by the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. This facility has a coin-operated laundromat and shower facilities. Located on the entrance road to the North Rim Campground, between the Service Station and the General Store. One accessible and three regular shower stalls are available in sections for both women and men, on the right side of the building.

images.altText: A single story brown wooden building with large white letters reads: "Showers, Laundromat"
images.title: Laundry and Showers
images.caption: Located across from the campground check-in kiosk, and between the service station and general store

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the campground, lodge, visitor center, and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

Located on the entrance road to the North Rim Campground, between the Service Station and the North Rim General Store, visitors will find coin-operated laundry and shower facilities. One accessible and three regular shower stalls are available in sections for both women and men, on the right side of the building.

When the facility reopens, six quarters provide a six minute shower. Paper currency (American) may be exchanged for quarters at the change machine inside the laundromat. An ATM is located inside the nearby North Rim General Store.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 16, Laundry & Showers. 1 ¾ minutes. Continuing south about two-tenths of a mile (320 meters) along Campground Road from the Service Station, we come to a parking lot along the right-hand (west) side of the road. A line of parallel spaces face a four-foot (one meter) wide concrete sidewalk in front of a low, one-story wooden building that houses the showers and laundry facilities. A sidewalk from the north and south ends of the parking lot run 10 feet (three meters) west to a concrete sidewalk in front of the 40-foot (12 meter) long structure. Moving along the southern sidewalk from the parking lot toward the building, note a metal, wildlife-proof garbage can at the right. A double door to the coin-operated laundromat is straight ahead. Moving through the door, there is a bank of washing machines along the right-hand wall, opposite a bank of dryers along the left-hand wall. A bill-changing machine is mounted on the far, back wall. To the left of the change machine, there is a folding table beyond the dryers, also on the left-hand wall. Moving north from the laundry room, along the wall note a bulletin board, and a coin-operated beverage machine, next to a row of small, built-in, wooden picnic tables. Note also there are electrical outlets located beside these tables on the outside wall of the structure. The showers are located along the far, north side of the building. There is a women’s wheelchair accessible shower located to the left, and a men’s wheelchair accessible shower at the far right. Hours are posted on the doors. Note there is a locked utility door between the two showers.

data.title: North Rim Entrance Station
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. Entrance to the North Rim of the park is located 31 miles (50 km) south of Jacob Lake on State Route 67; The actual rim of the canyon is an additional 13 miles (21 km) south of the entrance station. (Jacob Lake, AZ is located in northern Arizona at the intersection of Highway 89A, and State Route 67. Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona.

images.altText: A large brown wooden sign suspended by large wooden pillars reads Grand Canyon National Park
images.title: North Rim entrance sign
images.caption: The Entrance Station lies just beyond the large wooden sign welcoming visitors to the North Rim.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, campground and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

The entrance station for North Rim of the park is located 31 miles (50 km) south of Jacob Lake on Highway 67. Jacob Lake, Arizona, is located in northern Arizona on Highway 89A, not far from the Utah border. Grand Canyon lies entirely within the state of Arizona.

The actual rim of Grand Canyon, along with the the North Rim developed area (lodge and campground) is an additional 13 miles (21 km) south of the entrance station. 

  • Grand Canyon National Park will close the North Rim to all visitor access on Friday, November 14, 2025, at 5:20 p.m. Sections of the North Rim are tentatively expected to reopen to visitors for the 2026 season on May 15, pending weather, trail conditions, infrastructure readiness, and completion of hazard mitigation efforts.

Directions

Driving from the South Rim to the North Rim (or vice versa) by automobile requires a five-hour trip over 220 miles (354 km). Driving directions to the North Rim 

The hike across the canyon from rim to rim is 21 miles (34 km) via the South Kaibab Trail. However, due to the fire, the North Kaibab Trail is CLOSED — Extensive maintenance is required to address rockslides and make necessary structural modifications.

 Follow this link for today's inner canyon temperatures, heat risk, and water availability by location. 

A backcountry permit is required for all overnight hikes into the canyon.

Entrance Fees and Passes

Admission to Grand Canyon National Park is valid for seven days. It includes both the North Rim and South Rim.

No refunds are given due to inclement weather.

Vehicle Permit $35
Admits one single, private, non-commercial vehicle and all its passengers. Organized groups are not eligible for the vehicle permit.

Motorcycle Permit $30
Admits one single, private, non-commercial motorcycle and its passenger(s).

Individual Permit $20 per person
Admits one individual when entering by foot, bicycle, park shuttle bus, Grand Canyon Railway, and private rafting trip. Individuals 16 years of age and younger are admitted free of charge.

Annual Passes

There are several types of annual passes available at each of the park's three entrance stations:

America the Beautiful - Annual Pass ($80)
America the Beautiful - Annual Senior Pass ($20)
America the Beautiful - Lifetime Senior Pass ($80)
"Every Kid Outdoors" - 4th Grade Pass (Free)
America the Beautiful - Lifetime Access Pass (Free)
Military Pass (Free)
Grand Canyon National Park Pass ($70)

Detailed information about these passes, and which one is right for you: here 

Documentation and ID are required when presenting or acquiring a pass. 

At Grand Canyon National Park's Entrance Stations, credit and debit cards and America the Beautiful passes are accepted for entry. Cash is not accepted.

Group Tours

Organized, Non-commercial Groups
Organized, non-commercial groups include church groups, college or school groups, scouts, service organizations, military, etc.

Commercial Tours

Commercial Tour Fees
Fees are based on vehicle capacity for all tour groups and bus companies that originate outside a 100-mile (160 km) radius of an entrance station to Grand Canyon National Park. Taxis are classified as commercial tours since they do not have regularly scheduled service.

Educational Fee Waivers

Educational Fee Waivers are not issued automatically. Educational groups must apply and meet the criteria to receive a fee waiver. Details
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 12, North Rim Entrance Station. 2 minutes. The entrance to the North Rim of Grand Canyon National Park is located nearly 13 miles (21 kilometers) north of Grand Canyon Lodge on Highway 67. A few hundred feet (120 meters) north of the entrance station along the west side of the road, massive, eight foot (nearly three meter) tall, thick, round posts rise from a mound of large boulders; a third, horizontal wooden post spans the distance between them. A six foot wide by four foot tall (two by one and a half meter) wooden sign hangs suspended from wide, black metal bands wrapped around the top post. White carved lettering on the sign reads: “Entering Grand Canyon National Park, U.S. Department of the Interior, National Park Service.” A three-foot (one meter) tall National Park Service arrowhead logo emblazons the front of a wooden post to the right of the sign. About 10 feet (three meters) in front of the sign, lettering on a metal plaque embedded in a large boulder on the ground announces Grand Canyon National Park is a World Heritage Site. The park is open daily, from May 15th to October 15th. If you arrive when park rangers are not at the entrance station, and you are not a pass holder, please proceed to the automated fee station next to the North Rim Visitor Center. From November 1st to December 1st, the North Rim is open for "dawn to dusk" day use with limited services. However, if snow closes Highway 67 before December 1, the park will also close. Though road closures prevent vehicles from driving to the North Rim during the winter season, hikers, snowshoers, and cross country skiers may enter the North Rim of the park through the winter months, provided backcountry permits have been obtained. Personal snowmobiles are NOT permitted inside the park. The North Rim reopens on May 15 of every year.

data.title: North Rim General Store
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area, including the campground and general store, is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. -- At the campground entrance, the store offered coffee and quick breakfast items in the morning. It also had basic grocery items. Snacks, trail mixes, hiking accessories, soft and hard beverages, and souvenirs. There is a microwave, and just enough free Wi-Fi to check email.

images.altText: A large brown building with a green roof. A covered porch shelters the entry door.
images.title: North Rim General Store
images.caption: The one and only stop on the North Rim for groceries and camping supplies.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the campground, lodge, visitor center and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures


The North Rim General Store, at the entrance to the North Rim Campground, had a counter that offered coffee and ice cream throughout the day, and quick breakfast items in the morning. They also had basic grocery items and a wide variety of snacks and trail mixes. There was a microwave to warm your food.

Camping supplies along with Grand Canyon souvenirs, were available here. 

This was also the only building on Grand Canyon's North Rim that offered free Wi-Fi. Keep your expectations low: connectivity is slow, but adequate to check email.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 17, General Store. 2 ¼ minutes. From the Service Station, the General Store is located about three-tenths of a mile (480 meters) south along Campground Road, past the Laundry and Showers building, where it intersects the North Rim Campground Loop road in a ‘T.’ Straight ahead, across the road, a wide, concrete sidewalk edged with flat stones separates two small parking areas in front of the store, surrounding a tall, ponderosa pine at the right. Note two wheelchair accessible parking spaces to the left of the sidewalk. Additional parallel car parking spaces are available to the left and right. A concrete sidewalk in front of the parking areas meets up with a central, 10-foot (three meter) wide sidewalk that leads south about 20 feet to the covered, wood-plank porch of the General Store. Note along the sidewalk at the left are two conventional, green metal garbage cans next to a wildlife-proof garbage can. Two large diameter, eight-foot (two and a half meter) tall log posts support the porch roof in front at the left and right. A log railing runs along the front of both sides of the eight-foot deep porch. Note a number of small tables and chairs on the porch behind the railing at the left and right. Also note a number of chairs on the far side of the porch along the outside wall of the store. A fire extinguisher hangs on the outside wall to the left just beyond a window. Beyond a window to the right hangs a bulletin board with notifications about ranger programs in the park. Continue forward across the porch to a set of double wood and glass doors, and move inside the store. Here you’ll find a wide variety of groceries and gifts, first aid supplies, as well as camping gear and water filtration equipment. The checkout counter is located along the left-hand wall. Back outside the store, the sidewalk continues south along the side of the building to the women’s restroom, then continues south to the men’s restroom beyond. Note a small picnic area to the east of the Grocery Store, with several tables set under a high canopy of ponderosa pine.

data.title: North Rim Service Station
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. Self-service gasoline/diesel fuel was available here 24 hours, by card. The only gas station inside park boundaries (on North Rim) is located at the entrance to the campground road, near the General Store. Outside the park, the nearest lodging, food services, and fuel - open all year, are at Jacob Lake, 31 miles (50 km) north of the park's entrance station.

images.altText: a rustic brown building with garage doors and two gas pumps out front.
images.title: North Rim Service Station
images.caption: The only gas station inside the park, on the North Rim, is located near the campground.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the campground, service station, lodge, visitor center, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

Self-service gasoline and diesel fuel was available 24 hours, by debit or credit card.

The only service station within park boundaries (on the North Rim) was located just after turning onto the entrance road for the campground. The General Store and campground Laundry and Showers Building are nearby.

The information below describes normal operations —not valid when the service station and North Rim developed area are closed.

During the season, from May 15 to October 15, gasoline and diesel fuel are also available just outside the park, on State Route 67, at the North Rim Country Store (on the opposite side of the SR 67 from Kaibab Lodge and DeMotte Campground), 5.5 miles (9 km) north of the North Rim Entrance Station.

Open all year, Jacob Lake, Arizona, on State Route 67 is located 31 miles (50 km) north of the park's entrance station. Jacob Lake is the closest location with fuel, lodging, a restaurant and groceries during the off-season.
 

  • Between October 16, and November 30, when the North Rim of the park is open for day use only, and all visitor services have closed, fuel is still available at the North Rim Service Station by debit or credit card purchase, provided park roads are open.
 
  • During the winter months, the North Rim of the park and State Route 67, from Jacob Lake, Arizona, are closed to all vehicle traffic between December 1, and May 14.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 15, Service Station. 1 ½ minutes. The turnoff for the North Rim Service Station is located about one point two miles (two kilometers) north of Grand Canyon Lodge along Route 67. Turn left onto Campground Road, and continue about one-tenth of a mile (160 meters) along the paved, two-lane asphalt road to the pull-off at the right to the Sinclair service station. On the left side of the pullout is a single, modern gas-pump island with a single width lane on either side. To the right, a bicycle rack blocks the entrance to a vestigial gas-pump island, under a simple, flat overhang. Continuing to the right is the entrance to the office of a low, one-story brown building with several large, plate glass windows and a full-length wood and glass door. Inside there is a small wooden desk and a set of shelves along the wall behind it filled with several different brands of motor oil and other automotive fluids. Note that while there are two vehicle bays to the right of the office with large, rolling doors, no automobile repair or maintenance services are offered here. A picnic table stands in front of one of the bays. Outside, to the left of the office, is a wheelchair accessible Men’s room, and around a small stand of trees to the left is a similarly accessible Women’s room. These facilities are often closed, however, replaced by two portable toilets placed about 20 feet (six meters) to the left of the Women’s room along the far curb of the station.

data.title: Park Store at the Visitor Center - Grand Canyon Conservancy
data.listingDescription: Located on the south side of Grand Canyon Visitor Center Plaza, adjacent to parking lot 4. This large store features books, maps, apparel, souvenirs, and gifts to help you plan, or share your trip to Grand Canyon with friends and family back home. A large variety of publications provide in-depth information about the canyon's geology —as well as natural and cultural information. ► Follow the link for hours of operation.

images.altText: Two people walk out of a storefront; sign above them reads "Grand Canyon Conservancy Park Store"
images.title: Grand Canyon Conservancy Park Store
images.caption: Grand Canyon Conservancy Park Store at the Visitor Center Plaza.

data.bodyText:
Hours of Operation

Current Hours
Open Daily: 8 am to 6 pm

As the park's official nonprofit partner, the Grand Canyon Conservancy (GCC) works with the National Park Service to operate park stores in seven locations throughout the park. The largest store is located on the south side of the Visitor Center Plaza. Parking Lot 4 provides the closest access to the store.

The Park Store features a wide variety of books, maps, apparel, souvenirs, and gifts to help you to plan or remember your trip to Grand Canyon, and learn more about Grand Canyon geology, ecology, and history. Purchases help fund new exhibits, scientific research, trail restoration, wildlife monitoring, ecological restoration, support for the arts, Junior Ranger and education programs, and historic building preservation.

Additional GCC Stores

GCC operates several stores and sites on the South Rim of the park:

Grand Canyon Conservancy Park Store at the South Rim Visitor Center

  • Yavapai Geology Museum
 
  • Verkamp's Visitor Center - in Village Historic District
 
  • Kolb Studio - in Village Historic District
 
  • Desert View Watchtower  

Additional Information: 

Grand Canyon Conservancy

This stamp is slightly different from the one available at the nearby Grand Canyon Visitor Center, which reads "Grand Canyon, AZ" at the bottom. The Park Store also has a special Grand Canyon Conservancy stamp featuring a mule deer and the original name of the Visitor Center area, "Canyon View Information Plaza".

data.title: Picnic Area - Desert View Drive (Range Road)
data.listingDescription: Located in the forest, near mile marker 244, on the south side of SR 64 (Desert View Drive), this small picnic area offers tables with both sun and shade, There are no restrooms here, or view of Grand Canyon from this location.

images.altText: A weathered picnic table sits in a sunny spot within a forest of tall pine trees.
images.title: Picnic Table at SR 64 mile marker 244
images.caption: One of several quiet picnic areas in the ponderosa pine forest along Desert View Drive.

data.bodyText: Located in the ponderosa pine forest near mile marker 244 on the south side of SR 64 (Desert View Drive), this small picnic area offers tables in both sun and shade. There are no restrooms here, unfortunately, nor are there any views of Grand Canyon from this location.

data.title: Picnic Area - Long Jim Road
data.listingDescription: This picnic area, located near Mile Marker 248 near several small lookout points west of Grandview Point, has several picnic tables and is well shaded. Year-round ponderosa pines provide cover, while the spring and summer will some extra shade from a few local gamble oaks. There is, however, no view of Grand Canyon from here, nor are there restrooms.

images.altText: A wood and metal picnic table sits in the shade of pine trees.
images.title: Long Jim Road Picnic Area
images.caption: One of the quietest and shadiest spots for a picnic along Desert View Drive.

data.bodyText: This picnic area, located near Mile Marker 248 on the north side of SR 64 (Desert View Drive), has several picnic tables and is well shaded. Ponderosa pines provide year-round cover, while spring and summer feature even more shade from a few local gamble oaks. There is, however, unfortunately no view of Grand Canyon from here, nor are there restrooms.

data.title: Picnic Area - Yaki Point Rd.
data.listingDescription: This picnic area, located just east of the shuttle-bus-only Yaki Point Road on the south side of Desert View Drive, has shaded picnic tables and restrooms. There is, unfortunately, no view of Grand Canyon from this picnic area.

images.altText: A wood and metal picnic table sits in a patch of sunlight with a restroom in the distance
images.title: Picnic Area - Yaki Point
images.caption: This picnic area is very popular due to its proximity to the S. Kaibab Trailhead.

data.bodyText:
This picnic area, located just east of the shuttle-bus-only Yaki Point Road on the south side of Desert View Drive, has shaded picnic tables and restrooms. There is, unfortunately, no view of Grand Canyon from this picnic area.

This picnic area is very popular with both day and overnight hikers due to its proximity to the S. Kaibab Trail. Parking is very limited and generally not available within an hour or two of sunrise. If you are trying to access the S. Kaibab Trailhead, park in Lots 1–4 at the Grand Canyon Visitor Center and ride the free shuttle service to the trailhead. It is a short 6 minute ride and buses leave every 10–15 throughout the year from before sunrise till after sunset.

data.title: Pima Point
data.listingDescription: Pima Point is one of the best places on the rim to see, and sometimes even hear, the Colorado River. The distant roar of Granite Rapids far below can be heard echoing up the canyon walls on quiet days.

images.altText: A person leans across a railing and takes a photo of the canyon landscape beyond
images.title: Pima Point
images.caption: Pima point offers wide open views of Grand Canyon and the Colorado River

data.bodyText:
Pima Point is one of the best places on the rim to see, and sometimes even hear, the Colorado River. The distant roar of Granite Rapids far below can be heard echoing up the canyon walls on quiet days.

As you look west from Pima Point, take note of the 'Cataract Plains'. This incredibly flat plateau at 6,000-7,000 feet (1,828-2,134 m) is a product of many layers of rock eroding prior to the cutting of Grand Canyon.

The Greenway Trail continues from here to Hermits Rest, allowing bicyclists and visitors using wheelchairs to share the path with pedestrians.
data.audioDescription: From the shuttle bus stop, move 80 feet (24 m) east along a 2-foot (60 cm) high stone wall lining the inside of the asphalt sidewalk to a 3-foot (1 m) wide opening on your left. Move away from the road down three stone steps onto another asphalt sidewalk and proceed 20 feet (6 m) forward to a vast overlook lined with a 4-foot (1.2 m) tall metal railing running left-to-right along the edge of the canyon. At the northernmost corner of a wide promontory, Pima Point provides a vista of over 40 miles (64 km) along Grand Canyon, from Bright Angel Canyon in the east all the way west to Powell Plateau and the Great Scenic Divide. Grand Canyon rock layers are on full display from the 2-billion-year-old Vishnu Schist at the bottom of the canyon up through the various layers of sandstone, shale, and limestone all the way up to the rim. Far below, the Colorado River is visible in several places as it winds through deep gorges, including Granite Rapids to the east. Stand still, be quiet, close your eyes. Can you hear the distant roar of the rapids, or the wing beat of a passing raven? Various sections of the Hermit Trail are in view, zigzagging down through rocky buttes, as are the meandering paths of numerous side creeks lined with green vegetation. Debris flows appear in several places on the faces of the canyon walls, evidence of side washes where raging water rushed over cliff edges, triggering avalanches of rock, mud, water, and depositing boulders in their wake—sometimes all the way into the river below.

data.title: Pima Point Bus Stop - Hermits Rest (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: NO BUS SERVICE on Hermit Road during December, January and February. One of the few places where one can hear the Colorado River from the rim of Grand Canyon. Wait for the shuttle to pull away, then be as quiet as possible, and you might hear the faint roar of Granite Rapid far below, a sound which just barely hints at the power of a river more than 3 miles (4.8 km) away.

images.altText: a green and white bus pulling into a bus stop. a large tree is between the bus stop and a paved path
images.title: Pima Point
images.caption: Eastbound and westbound shuttles use this bus stop at Pima Point

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.



TWO WAY STOP - Outbound to Hermits Rest — Inbound to the Village

Pima Point is of the few places where it is possible to hear the Colorado River from the rim of Grand Canyon, on a relatively quiet day, and when wind conditions are just right.

Wait for the shuttle to pull away, then be as quiet as possible, and you may be able to hear the faint roar of Granite Rapid far below, a sound which just barely hints at the power of a river more than 3 miles (4.8 km) away.

Hermits Rest (Red) Route 

Tentative Spring 2026 Schedule - Starting March 1
80 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)
 
  • First bus leaves Hermit Transfer Station at 8:00 am. 
  • Buses run every 10-15 minutes.
  • Last bus - one hour after sunset.
  • Be at a bus stop 30 minutes after sunset

 

Route Information

From the Pima Point shuttle stop, one can board buses traveling both outbound towards Hermits Rest and inbound towards Grand Canyon Village.

From the Pima Point shuttle stop, inbound buses stop at the following locations on their way back to the Village:

  • Mohave Point (inbound)
  • Powell Point (inbound)
  • Village Route Transfer Station

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Pipe Creek Vista
data.listingDescription: This is the first pullout on the left as you head east toward Desert View on Desert View Drive. It can be accessed by private vehicle or by using the free Kaibab/Rim Route (Orange) shuttle bus, which departs from the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal. Pipe Creek Vista is not the "biggest" view of the canyon, but the drainage stretching away from you is nicely framed by Mather and Yaki points.

images.altText: Three people stand on an outcropping of rock looking out over Grand Canyon
images.title: Pipe Creek Vista
images.caption: The view provides access to canyon views — with and without railings. Be Careful!!

data.bodyText:
Pipe Creek Vista is the first pullout on the left as you head east toward Desert View on Desert View Drive (State Route 64 East). It can be accessed by private vehicle or by using the free Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route shuttle bus, which departs from the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal.

Because this is the first scenic overlook east of the junction with South Entrance Road, this area can become quite congested with vehicle traffic. If that is the case when you arrive, continue driving east to Duck on a Rock, or Twin Overlooks.  

Pipe Creek Vista is not the "biggest" view of the canyon, but the drainage stretching away from you is nicely framed by Mather and Yaki points. As you stand along the rim at this viewpoint, observe the canyon walls below as well—you might notice a forest of Douglas fir. This is an example of a micro-habitat fueled by water and cooler temperatures resulting from shade cast by the canyon cliffs. This, combined with the canyon's thermals, make it an excellent stop for birding, especially in the spring and fall during the major migrations.

The Canyon Rim Trail may be accessed here, with a 1.4 miles (2.3 km) walk on a paved trail west to Mather Point, or a 0.9 mile (1.4 km) walk east to the South Kaibab Trailhead. Either way, you will be treated with great views of the canyon as you walk the trail. This section of the Canyon Rim Trail is also part of the Greenway Trail, meaning that it is open to bicycles.
data.audioDescription: A low limestone wall runs along the north side of an asphalt paved sidewalk at the 60-foot (18 m) long shuttle bus stop, here at Pipe Creek Vista. The wall continues 100 feet (30 m) east past some additional parking spaces. This viewpoint looks down onto Pipe Creek, the major canyon between the South Kaibab Trail and the Bright Angel Trail. Douglas-fir trees thrive in a shielded niche just below the rim where there is sufficient water to sustain their survival. A 4-foot (1.2 m) tall metal railing runs along the rim offering many vistas, beside a small forest of ponderosa pine, and pinyon-juniper woodland. The shaggy, twisty shrub known as cliffrose is also found in this area. It has reddish-brown bark, and blooms persistently and profusely from spring through fall. The blossoms are creamy or yellowish, up to an inch wide and quite fragrant. Listen for birds as this is also a prime bird migratory path across the canyon. The Rim Trail follows the rim from Pipe Creek Vista west to Hermits Rest. The section of the Rim Trail between Pipe Creek Vista and Maricopa Point is paved, and mostly wheelchair accessible.

data.title: Pipe Creek Vista Bus Stop - Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route
data.listingDescription: Located west of Yaki Point and the South Kaibab Trailhead, this shuttle stop provides visitors with spectacular views across the canyon from South Rim to North Rim. The paved Canyon Rim Trail may be accessed here. This section of the Rim Trail is also part of the Greenway bicycle path, which runs east 0.9-mile (1.4 km) from here to the South Kaibab Trailhead and west 1.4-mile (2.3 km) to the Visitor Center. Visit the link for the current schedule.

images.altText: An empty bus stop with an orange and white sign
images.title: Pipe creek shuttle stop
images.caption: This shuttle stop is on the edge of the canyon. There is roadside parking here, it can be congested.

data.bodyText:
Nearby:

  • Scenic Overlook
  • Canyon Rim Trail Access


Located west of Yaki Point and the South Kaibab Trailhead, this shuttle stop provides visitors with spectacular views across the canyon from South Rim to North Rim. There is limited roadside parking here, and the area can become quite congested since this is the closest pullout to the village along Desert View Drive.

All buses that stop here are inbound to the Visitor Center. 

The paved Canyon Rim Trail may be accessed here, with a 1.4-mile (2.3 km) walk west to Mather Point, or a 0.9-mile (1.4 km) walk east to South Kaibab Trailhead. It is possible to get off the bus at this stop, enjoy a scenic walk along the rim, then get back on the bus at the next stop and return to the Visitor Center.

This section of the Canyon Rim Trail is part of a multi-use greenway —bicycles may also travel on this trail, east to South Kaibab Trailhead and west to the Visitor Center/ Mather Point. 

Kaibab (Orange) Route - Winter Schedule

December 1, 2025, through February 28, 2026
50 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)

First bus is at 8:00 am — last bus is at 7:00 pm
► Be at a bus stop no later than 6:45 pm

  • Every 20 minutes: 8:00 am to 10:30 am
  • Every 15 minutes: 10:30am to 3:30 pm
  • Every 20 minutes: 3:30 pm to 7:00 pm

Need access to or from the South Kaibab Trailhead when the shuttle buses are not running? Please contact Xanterra Taxi Service at (928) 638-2631. 

Route Information

The Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route is a shuttle bus loop that takes approximately 50 minutes to ride the entire route and return to the same location. At the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal, there are separate stops for the eastbound and westbound shuttles. Additional bus stops are at the following locations:


Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal (eastbound)

  • South Kaibab Trailhead
  • Yaki Point
  • Pipe Creek Vista


Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal (westbound)

  • Mather Point
  • Yavapai Geology Museum

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).
  • No eating or open drink containers.

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.
data.audioDescription: Overlooking the canyon, a low limestone wall, runs along the north side of an asphalt paved sidewalk on the edge of a 2 lane highway. The shuttle bus stop is 60-foot (18 m) long here at Pipe Creek Vista. The stone wall continues 100 feet (30 m) to the east, past a number of parallel parking spaces. This area often becomes congested with vehicle traffic. The bus stop is located within a ponderosa pine and pinyon-juniper woodland.
