data.title: Trailview Overlook Bus Stop - Hermits Rest (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: A short walk down the stairs from the parking/shuttle stop is the best location for aerial views of the sinuous switchbacks on Bright Angel Trail. From the viewpoint you can see everything from where the trail starts just west of the historic village down, and down, and down to Havasupai Gardens, until the trail finally disappears into the depths of the inner gorge. —NO BUS SERVICE during December, January and February.

images.altText: A couple sits on a rock wall along the rim of Grand Canyon next to a shuttle stop with a red sign.
images.title: Trailview Overlook Shuttle Stop
images.caption: Walking down the stairs from the shuttle stop gives excellent views of the Bright Angel Trail.

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.


This stop is outbound only - to Hermits Rest

Nearby:

  • Canyon Overlook
  • Canyon Rim Trail access

A short walk down the stairs from the shuttle stop is the best location for aerial views of the sinuous switchbacks of Bright Angel Trail. From this viewpoint, you can see everything —from where the trial starts just west of the historic village, down, and down, 3000 feet (914 m) to Havasupai Garden, until the trail finally disappears into the depths of the inner gorge.

Looking south and southeast you can see the Historic District of Grand Canyon Village, a collection of hotels and visitor services that has retained much of its orignial character from the early 20th Century.  Further to the south, the hazy blue mountains of the San Francisco Volcanic Field rise above the Coconino Plateau to dot the horizon, with the snow-capped San Francisco Peaks towering the highest.

From this overlook, you can walk downhill along the Canyon Rim Trail, 0.7 miles (1.1 km) and return to the village. 

Hermits Rest (Red) Route 

Tentative Spring 2026 Schedule - Starting March 1
80 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)
 
  • First bus leaves Hermit Transfer Station at 8:00 am. 
  • Buses run every 10-15 minutes.
  • Last bus - one hour after sunset.
  • Be at a bus stop 30 minutes after sunset

Route Information

If you simply ride this shuttle bus without getting off at any stop, the entire loop will take approximately 80 minutes to return to where you started.

From the Trailview Overlook shuttle stop, buses only travel outbound (westbound) towards Hermits Rest, stopping at the following locations. 

 

  • Maricopa Point

  • Powell Point (Outbound)

  • Hopi Point

  • Mohave Point (Outbound)

  • The Abyss

  • Monument Creek Vista

  • Pima Point (Outbound)

  • Hermits Rest

The buses turn around at Hermits Rest, then return inbound (eastbound) to the Village, stopping only at the following locations:

  • Pima Point (Inbound)
  • Mohave Point (Inbound)
  • Powell Point (Inbound)
  • Village Route Transfer

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.
     

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.
data.audioDescription: From the Trailview Overlook shuttle bus stop, two ramps lead north through the low limestone wall lining the sidewalk. A couple wooden benches sit on a flat, pebbly area on the other side of the wall between the two entrance points, across some low limestone boulders lining the asphalt path. Ten feet (3 m) to the east of a vertical wayside panel with an eight-foot (2.4 m) wide limestone base, a long set of concrete stairs, four-feet (1.2 m) wide with metal handrails on both sides, leads down to an overlook. Move 16 steps down to a concrete sidewalk. Follow 20 feet (6 m) along the right handrail to two more steps, then continue 20 feet (6 m) forward to where another set of stairs leads down to the right with handrails on both sides. Follow along the right handrail to move down a series of staircases and landings down a total of 54 stairs to an asphalt-paved path. Turn left and continue 25 feet (8 m) along the handrail at your right to an overlook area ringed by a four-foot (1.2 m) high metal railing. At the left, text on a three-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel reads: Breaking Ground Look down Garden Creek Canyon at the winding Bright Angel Trail. The Earth’s crust fractured in this area, lifting one side of the rock layers and lowering the other, creating a fault. The trail follows this fault into the canyon. Water also follows the fault. Springs, like those at Indian Garden, are able to flow because the groundwater has reached impermeable rock, where it spreads out sideways and leaks out of the canyon walls as springs. A picture of the canyon from this vantage point fills the bottom two-thirds of the panel. A thick yellow line in the middle of the panel shows the location of the Bright Angel Fault, running across the bottom of the canyon through Indian Garden all the way across to the North Rim. A circular picture inset at the lower left shows your location as viewed from the North Rim of the canyon. Two cliff faces are highlighted with arrows, one pointing down, the other pointing up. A caption reads: Sixty million years ago the west side of Bright Angel Fault was lifted higher than the east side.

data.title: Train Depot
data.listingDescription: Constructed in 1909-1910, the Train Depot is a National Historic Landmark and is one of 14 log depots constructed in the United States and one of only three remaining. Grand Canyon Railway provides daily service to and from Williams, Arizona and Grand Canyon National Park. An agent is present in the depot from 11:45 am to 3 pm daily.

images.altText: Along railroad tracks, a log building, mostly one story, with a two story section in the center.
images.title: Grand Canyon Railway Depot.
images.caption: Grand Canyon Railway Depot sits at the end of the railroad tracks down the hill from El Tovar Hotel

data.bodyText:
Grand Canyon Railway provides service to and from Williams, Arizona and Grand Canyon National Park. Service occurs throughout the year, weather permitting. 

There is limited parking near the depot, however, there is a Village (Blue) Route shuttle bus stop, across the street. 

Train Reservations

To book a trip, make reservations online: 
https://www.thetrain.com/the-train/schedule-route/

or call: 

1-800-THE-TRAIN (800-843-8724)
From outside US: +1-303-843-8724
Fax: 307-344-7456

info-gcr@xanterra.com


An agent is present in the depot from 11:45 am to 3 pm daily. 

History

Each day as the whistle sounds and another train pulls into station, the Train Depot reminds visitors of earlier days at Grand Canyon. The first train arrived in 1901, bringing passengers ready to marvel at Grand Canyon's one-of-a-kind views. Today this feeling continues as folks step off the train, eager to make the walk up towards El Tovar Hotel and the canyon rim.

Constructed in 1909-1910, the Train Depot is part of the Grand Canyon National Park National Historic Landscape District and a designated National Historic Landmark. Designed by architect Francis W. Wilson of Santa Barbara, California, the log and wood-frame structure is two stories high.

Originally, the downstairs was designated for station facilities and the station agent's family inhabited the upstairs. Today, the first floor is used for railway passenger services. The building is one of 14 log depots constructed in the United States and one of only three remaining. Of the three, the Train Depot is the only one in which logs were used as the primary structural material and which still serves an operating railroad. The depot's logs are squared on three sides creating bearing surfaces, flat interior surfaces, and a rustic exterior appearance.

Just beyond the depot is the El Tovar Hotel, built in 1905 by the Santa Fe Railroad. The structure is the signature hotel along the rim. The railroad built the Train Depot five years after the hotel and placed it conveniently close for the rail passengers.
data.audioDescription:
Grand Canyon Railway Depot sits at the end of the railroad tracks down the hill from El Tovar. The main facade faces south, away from the canyon.
The 3,000-square foot (900 square meter) log structure is primarily a one-story building with a broad, moderately-pitched gable roof with the ridge running on the long axis, parallel to the four sets of train tracks, thirty feet (9 m) across. A frame second story occupies the center third of the building, sheathed with flush planking framed by vertical log posts. This central portion is covered with another broad gabled roof at right angles to the main roof. The second story overhangs the first, supported by heavy vertical log posts, and an attic overhangs the second story, supported by log brackets. An extension of the main roof to the west at a slightly lower elevation shelters a large two-bay porch, supported on vertical log posts, and a small one-story bay projects slightly from the central block. Note there is a set of men's restrooms outside on the back-north side of the building, towards the east.
Inside, there are four main rooms. From west to east there is a ticket office-waiting room with several wooden benches and metal railings, an agent's office, a parcel storage room and a baggage room. Family and women's restrooms are between these rooms and the platform. Interior walls are plastered with log-slab wainscoting. Note that much of the original hardware is present. Feel the doorknobs, stamped with the letters, "GC."
Back outside, there are a couple picnic tables underneath a tree to the east of the station next to the tracks.

On the south side of the depot, just east of the large two-bay porch, an old black-and-white picture of the train station fills the top of a three-foot (1 m) tall angled metal wayside panel. Text at the top left reads:
"Grand Canyon Depot
In 1901, the screech of train brakes and the blast of a train whistle signaled the arrival of a new era in Grand Canyon Village. The railroad provided the most comfortable means of transportation to the canyon for more than a quarter century. This log depot, finished in 1910, welcomed train passengers to a growing village. By 1924, a community development plan was created for the village. Almost a century later, that planned community forms the core of Grand Canyon Village, centering on the last operational log depot in the country. Today, the depot is carefully preserved and still welcomes passengers to the canyon."
A smaller black-and-white picture at the lower left shows a black steam engine trailed by several cars next to a small wooden structure at the left. A caption reads:
"The original depot was a small shack located west of here. The need for a larger, more sophisticated structure quickly became apparent."
Two more black-and-white photos along the right side of the panel show long lines of a half-dozen trains in front of the depot, and a parking lot full of vintage cars next to the tracks. A caption reads:
These photos depict a thriving Grand Canyon rail operation, but with the opening of the paved automotive highway from Williams, Arizona, in 1926, that began to change. Ridership declined for decades. Finally, in 1968, the passenger service and depot closed.
A color photograph at the bottom right shows a black steam engine and coal car with several trailing cars in front of the station. Another caption reads:
"In 1989, passenger service resumed, bringing thousands of visitors to Grand Canyon by rail each year. Traveling this way lessens auto congestion on traffic-busy park roads."

On the south side of the depot, beside two large logs in the middle of the two-bay porch, is an 18-inch (46 cm) square metal plaque mounted on an angle to the top of a four-foot (1.2 m) tall wooden pedestal. Text on the plaque reads:
"Grand Canyon Railway Depot has been designated a National Historic Landmark. This site possesses national significance in commemorating the history of the United States of America, 1987, National Park Service, United States Department of the Interior."

data.title: Transept Trail (Grand Canyon Lodge)
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area, along with the Transept Trail are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. This moderate level trail wanders up and down the canyon rim along the Transept, a beautiful side canyon to the west of Grand Canyon Lodge and the campground. It also links to the northern portion of Bridle Path and the Backcountry Info Center. While this trail is not overly difficult, some portions are steep.

images.altText: A brown sign shows arrows to the start of Transept Trail and Nature Trail.
images.title: Start of Transept Trail
images.caption: Start of Transept Trail

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the Transept Trail, lodge, visitor center and campground, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

This moderate level trail wanders up and down the canyon rim along The Transept, a beautiful side canyon to the west of Grand Canyon Lodge and North Rim Campground. It also links to the northern portion of Bridle Path and the Backcountry Information Center. While this trail is not overly difficult, be advised that some portions wind steeply through woodlands and open vistas.

Be on the lookout for mule deer and other wildlife!

Trail Information

Roundtrip Distance: 2.0 miles (3.2 km), one-way
Elevation change: ~100 feet (~30 m)
Average Hiking Time: 1-2 hours, one-way

data.title: Tribal Medallion
data.listingDescription:
The canyon has been a site of value, beauty, adventure, peace, and even home far longer than it has been a national park. For thousands of years the canyon has sustained a wide variety of cultures and people as each in turn claimed it as their own and grew to know and love its gifts and challenges.

This medallion recognizes and honors the 11 Traditionally Associated Tribes that have known the canyon as a home and provider as well as site of continued cultural importance to this day.

images.altText: Visitors with a stroller walk next to a large bronze circular plaque set in the center of an open, concrete court area. The bronze plaque is decorated with an image of the canyon and a traditional southwestern petroglyph-style hand in the center. Surrounding the plaque is a large sun motif etched into the cement, along with the names of eleven local Native American tribes. Large, looming pieces of white-tan limestone encircle the court.
images.caption: The medallion reminds us of the thousands of years of human connections to Grand Canyon.

data.bodyText:
The canyon has been a site of value, beauty, adventure, peace, and even home far longer than it has been a national park. For thousands of years the canyon has sustained a wide variety of cultures and people as each in turn claimed it as their own and grew to know and love its gifts and challenges.

This medallion recognizes and honors the 11 Traditionally Associated Tribes that have known the canyon as a home and provider as well as site of continued cultural importance to this day.
data.audioDescription:
Along the path leading from Grand Canyon Visitor Center to Mather Point, a large circular medallion, 20-feet (6 m) in diameter, is sandblasted into the pavement.
The names of the eight cultural groups, listed around the edges of the medallion, represent the Traditionally Associated Tribes of Grand Canyon. They are shown in the general direction of each of their current homelands. These tribes include the Havasupai, Hopi, Hualapai, Southern Paiute, Navajo, Zuni, and Yavapai-Apache.
The central theme of the canyon is seen in the stair steps depicted in the center, surrounded by stars that represent the constellations. Water symbols on the outer ring, appearing as stylized curlicues or waves, signify the ongoing importance of rain and water in the desert southwest. The image of a hand in the center of the stairs is a reminder of all who have come this way before.
This tribal medallion, a collaboration between park staff and tribal colleagues, was developed as a way to introduce people to the native cultures that maintain strong cultural and spiritual ties to the canyon.

data.title: Verkamp's Visitor Center
data.listingDescription: In the Village Historic District, near Hopi House and El Tovar Hotel, Verkamp's Visitor Center features exhibits that focus on the Grand Canyon Community; what it was like to live and work here on the brink of one of the seven natural wonders. A staffed information desk and a Grand Canyon Conservancy Museum Store are also located here. Public restrooms are available in a separate building behind the Visitor Center. Follow the link for hours of operation ►

images.altText: A two-story craftsman style building with the entrance in the center four large window within arches
images.title: Verkamp's Visitor Center in the evening
images.caption: Verkamp's Visitor Center in the evening

data.bodyText:
Hours of Operation
Open Daily: 8 am to 6 pm

In the Village Historic District, near Hopi House and El Tovar Hotel, Verkamp's Visitor Center features exhibits that focus on the Grand Canyon Community--what it was like to live and work here on the brink of one of the seven natural wonders. A staffed information desk and a Grand Canyon Conservancy Museum Store are also located here. Public restrooms are available in a separate building behind Verkamp's Visitor Center.

Parking is available. It is also possible to ride the Village (Blue) Route shuttle from the Visitor Center or walk the Canyon Rim Trail from the Visitor Center/Mather Point, a distance of 2.1 miles (3.4 km).

Verkamp’s Visitor Center was originally known as Verkamp's Curios Store, built by the Verkamp family as one of the first shops along the canyon rim that catered to early tourists by offering gifts and locally-sourced and inspired souvenirs. The store was also the last family-run business in the park. From the early 1900s to early 2000s, the Verkamp family was a fixture of Grand Canyon National Park and their store was frequented by canyon visitors throughout the years.

The Grand Canyon Conservancy operates a Park Store in the building which sells books, souvenirs, and gifts. Restrooms are located in a separate building adjacent to the parking lot.

The Museum Features:

  • Bookstore and Museum Shop
  • Exhibits (about early Euro-American settlement at the Grand Canyon)
  • Public Restrooms in a separate building behind Verkamp’s
data.audioDescription: About 300 feet (90 m) east of El Tovar and Hopi House sits the grey-shingled, two-story Verkamp's Visitor Center. Nearby, an old black-and-white picture of the structure fill a three-foot (1 m) tall, angled metal wayside panel. Text at the top left reads: "Verkamp's Curios Store Inspired by Grand Canyon's burgeoning tourism trade, in 1898, John Verkamp established a small tent shop on the South Rim, selling American Indian arts and crafts. Profits proved meager, so John sold his inventory to the Bright Angel Hotel and closed his shop. Returning in 1905, John built the permanent store you see today. His business prospered; indeed, it was his only business to survive the Great Depression. In 1936, John, his wife, and their four children moved into the apartment above the store. John managed the store until his death in 1944. His children, and eventually his grandchildren, operated the store. When it closed in 2008, it was the last echo of the canyon's pioneer businesses." A caption underneath the photograph reads: "Verkamp hired El Tovar architect Charles F. Whittlesey to design his new store. Today, it serves as a visitor center." At the top right, an entry from John Verkamp's ledger on the opening day of his permanent curios store, January 31, 1906, reads: "$4.98. A good day." A black-and-white photograph inset at the lower left shows a man in a light-colored suit and vest standing before a makeshift white tent. A caption reads: "Verkamp traded flour, sugar, and other things to local tribes in exchange for hand-made jewelry, rugs, and pottery which he sold from this tent in 1898." Note there is a water filling station about 12 feet (3.6 m) to the left of this wayside.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Verkamp's Visitor Center has its own official passport stamp, with "Verkamp's Visitor Center" in green font along the bottom of the stamp. This contact station and store also carries a Grand Canyon Conservancy stamp with an image of a flying condor above the words, "Verkamp's Visitor Center Grand Canyon" in green ink.

data.title: Village Amphitheater (South Rim)

images.altText: Alongside a paved footpath, 35 people are sitting on stone benches listening to a park ranger talk.
images.title: South Rim - Village Amphitheater
images.caption: Ranger program at the Village Amphitheater along the Canyon Rim Trail in the Historic District.

data.bodyText:
Village Amphitheater is located in the Village Historic District, west of El Tovar Hotel and between Thunderbird and Kachina lodges along the Canyon Rim Trail. 

This outdoor venue serves as a space for interpretive programs, educational talks, and cultural presentations. 

Open-air setting and stone benches blend into the surrounding environment, allowing visitors to enjoy the presentations with views of Grand Canyon as a backdrop.

During warmer months (spring, summer and fall) programs may be presented here. Schedules vary, so check the calendar in the mobile app, or stop by the Visitor Center for details.
data.audioDescription: Facing the canyon, the amphitheater is situated alongside the paved Canyon Rim Trail in the Village Historic District, west of El Tovar Hotel and nestled between Kachina and Thunderbird Lodges. These two-story lodge buildings feature large picture windows and are constructed with beige-colored bricks. In addition to the Canyon Rim Trail, several other footpaths converge at this location. An asphalt footpath from Kachina Lodge approaches the amphitheater from the east, while a flagstone footpath from Thunderbird Lodge approaches from the west. From the flagstone footpath, a 30 ft, rock-lined dirt path enters at the rear of the amphitheater.

data.title: Village East Bus Stop - Village (Blue) Route
data.listingDescription: This stop is adjacent to the Xanterra's Public Grarage and General Offices. On the other side of the footbridge is the Village Greenway Trail, a paved path for foot and bicycle traffic that connects the Village to Market Plaza. This is the last shuttle stop in the historic village before the (Blue) Route bus returns to Shrine of the Ages, the campgrounds, Market Plaza, and Grand Canyon Visitor Center. Visit the link for the current schedule.

images.altText: A wooden benches next to a shuttle bus stop. A wooden footbridge in the background.
images.title: Village East Shuttle Stop
images.caption: From this stop, buses head eastbound, returning to campgrounds, Market Plaza and the Visitor Center

data.bodyText:
Nearby:

  • Xanterra Public Garage
  • Xanterra General Offices
  • Village Greenway Trail

This open-air stop is on the far east side of the Village Historic District. It is adjacent to the Xanterra's Public Grarage and General Offices. On the other side of the footbridge is the Village Greenway Trail, a paved path for foot and bicycle traffic.

This is the last shuttle stop in the historic village before the Village (Blue) Route bus returns to Shrine of the Ages, the campgrounds, Market Plaza, and Grand Canyon Visitor Center. 

From this shuttle stop, it is possible to walk to the canyon rim, but it is a bit of a challenge. Head west along the sidewalk and then cross over to the north side of the road at the three-way intersection. Across from the Train Depot, you can climb the stairs, or a separate paved wheelchair accessible path, up the hill to the canyon rim near El Tovar Hotel and Hopi House.

If you are finishing a walk along the Canyon Rim Trail, and want to return to Market Plaza or the Visitor Center —and you find yourself by El Tovar Hotel — take the stairs or ramp down the hill, then turn left at the three-way intersection, cross the road, and walk a little further to the Village East bus stop. You will save some time by not having to ride the shuttle around the entire historic village, with its five bus stops. 

Village (Blue) Route - Winter Schedule

December 1, 2025, through February 28, 2026
50 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)

First bus at 8:00 am — the last bus is at 8:00 pm.
► Be at a bus stop no later than 7:45 pm.

  • Every 20 minutes: 8:00 am to 10:30 am
  • Every 10 minutes: 10:30am to 3:30 pm
  • Every 15 minutes: 3:30 pm to 5:30 pm
  • Every 20 minutes: 5:30 pm to 8:00 pm

Route Information

The Village (Blue) Route is a loop route that takes approximately 50 minutes to return to the same location. From the Village East shuttle stop, the bus heads east towards Market Plaza, making stops at the following locations:

  • Shrine of the Ages (Eastbound)
  • Mather Campground
  • Trailer Village
  • Market Plaza (Eastbound)
  • Grand Canyon Visitor Center
  • Market Plaza (Westbound)
  • Shrine of the Ages (Westbound)
  • Train Depot and El Tovar Hotel
  • Bright Angel Lodge
  • Hermits Rest Route Transfer
  • Maswik Lodge
  • Backcountry Information Center
  • Center Road
  • Village East

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.
     

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Village Transfer Station - Hermit Road (Red) Route
data.listingDescription: NO BUS SERVICE during winter. Located west of Bright Angel Lodge, at the start of Hermit Road and beside a canyon overlook, this shuttle stop is just a few steps west of the Village (Blue) Route shuttle stop for the Hermit Road Interchange and Bright Angel Trailhead (at the top of the hill on your right. Hermit Road is a scenic 7-mile (11 km) road out to Hermits Rest, and the Hermit Trail. Along the way, there are 9 outstanding viewpoints, each with a designated bus stop.

images.altText: A long line of people wait under a peaked shade structure at a bus stop marked by a red sign.
images.title: Village Transfer shuttle stop
images.caption: Start the Hermits Rest (Red) Route here or take a hike up the Rim Trail to Trailview Overlook.

data.bodyText:
NOT IN SERVICE DURING THE WINTER

Hermit Road is open to private vehicles (under 22 feet) during the months of December, January and Februay, when there is no bus service.

  • Between March 1, and November 30, Hermit Road can only be accessed by the free Hermits Rest (Red) Route shuttle bus, on foot, bicycle, or by commercial tour.

This stop is outbound only - to Hermits Rest

Located west of Bright Angel Lodge, at the start of Hermit Road, this covered shuttle bus stop is just a few steps beyond the look-alike Village (Blue) Route shuttle stop for Bright Angel Trailhead/Hermit Road Interchange.

  • During the summer season, boarding lines can be long at the Hermit Road Transfer Station – you may have to wait for two to three buses. Arrive early in the morning for shorter lines. 

Before getting on the bus, take a moment to look over the canyon rim here. Below, you will see the start of the Bright Angel Trail, with intrepid hikers making their way up and down the switchbacks. The next stop, Trailview Overlook, will give you a grand sense of the journey that awaits those hiking thousands of feet down into the canyon. 

From this transfer station, board the Hermit Road (Red) Route bus to experience
the scenic 7 mile (11 km) road out to Hermits Rest, and Hermit Trailhead.

There are 9 outstanding viewpoints along the road, each with a designated bus stop.

The Canyon Rim Trail also follows the rim of the canyon for 7.8 miles (12.6 km) alongside Hermit Road, and offers the opportunity for short or long walks between viewpoints — on both paved and dirt trails. 

The shuttles are great when you use them in conjunction with the rim trail —you can get off at one stop, enjoy a scenic walk along the rim, then get back on a bus at the next stop.

Hermits Rest (Red) Route 

Tentative Spring 2026 Schedule - Starting March 1
80 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)
 
  • First bus leaves Hermit Transfer Station at 8:00 am. 
  • Buses run every 10-15 minutes.
  • Last bus - one hour after sunset.
  • Be at a bus stop 30 minutes after sunset

Route Information

If you simply ride this shuttle bus without getting off at any stop, the entire loop will take approximately 80 minutes to return to where you started. From the Village Route Transfer shuttle stop, all buses travel outbound to Hermits Rest.

  • Trailview Overlook (outbound only)
  • Maricopa Point (outbound only)
  • Powell Point (outbound and inbound)
  • Hopi Point (outbound only)
  • Mohave Point (outbound and inbound)
  • The Abyss (outbound only)
  • Monument Creek Vista (outbound only)
  • Pima Point (outbound and inbound)
  • Hermits Rest (inbound only)

The buses turn around at Hermits Rest, then return to the Village, stopping only at the following locations:

  • Pima Point (outbound and inbound)
  • Mohave Point (outbound and inbound)
  • Powell Point (outbound and inbound)
  • Village Route Transfer Station

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No eating or open drink containers.

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Vista Encantada
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, campground are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. A picnic area with a view. Located just northwest from Roosevelt Point on Cape Royal Road, this is a fantastic place to enjoy a picnic beneath Ponderosa pine trees by the canyon rim. Parking is limited in this tranquil setting.

images.altText: A wooden sign with "Vista Encantada" is surrounded by green grass and bushy pine needles.
images.title: Vista Encantada
images.caption: Seen from the parking lot, the sign for Vista Encantada, where several picnic tables are provided..

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, campground and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

A picnic area with a view.

Travelling south along Cape Royal Road, about five miles (eight kilometers) south of the ‘Y,’ past a series of curvy switchbacks, a small pullout to the left leads to the one-lane parking area of Vista Encantada. Parking is limited in this tranquil setting.

Located just northwest from Roosevelt Point on Cape Royal Road, this is a fantastic place to enjoy a picnic beneath Ponderosa pine trees by the canyon rim. Several picnic tables are provided.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 6, Vista Encantada. 2 minutes. Travelling south along Cape Royal Road, about five miles (eight kilometers) south of the ‘Y,’ past a series of curvy switchbacks, a small pullout to the left leads to the one-lane parking area of Vista Encantada. At the north end of the pullout, a line of parking spaces faces a six-foot wide asphalt sidewalk and the rim. Further south, additional parallel parking spaces line the sidewalk. Towards the middle, the sidewalk loops toward the rim (east) to encircle an eight-foot (two-and-a-half meter) tall, double-sided, wooden wayside with a small shingle roof sitting atop a three-foot tall by four-foot wide (90 by 120 centimeter) stone base. Flat boulders ring the edge of the wayside sidewalk loop at the rim, behind a few tall Ponderosa pine trees and the canyon vista beyond. Note there are no guardrails. To the south of the wayside beyond the sidewalk, note a 15 foot (six meter) wide dirt and gravel area in front of the rim, under a tall Ponderosa pine and a large boulder at the rim itself. If you visit during the summer, Vista Encantada may be bursting with orange and yellow wildflowers, and blooming prickly pear cactus. September through December, the small fruit turns ruby red when ripe. Continuing south along the sidewalk from the wayside overlook, the path curves around to a fork where a second asphalt loop path leads left into and around a grove of trees. Under the canopy are a half-dozen picnic tables. About 20 feet (six meters) along the left-hand hand path, a wooden bench at the left peers out over the edge of the canyon. Note a pair of wildlife-proof, metal garbage cans by the sidewalk in front of the picnic area.

data.title: Walhalla Glades Pueblo
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. Excavated by Douglas W. Schwartz in the 1960's, this Ancestral Puebloan archaeological site is an example of a small pueblo that had at least nine rooms. It was occupied from 1,100 to 1,150 CE. The site of seasonal farming, the inhabitants probably descended into the canyon and lived there during winter months.

images.altText: A brown sign that reads "Walhalla Pueblo" next to a trail leading into the forest.
images.title: Walhalla Glades Pueblo
images.caption: Walhalla Glades Pueblo trail.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center, campground and Bright Angel Point, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

Click and save me before you go: Walking Tour Guide

History

Ancestors of some of the 11 tribes traditionally associated with Grand Canyon, the Ancestral Puebloan people, lived both below and above the canyon rim about 1000 years ago. Archeological sites like this one are sacred to the tribes today, and require respect and care when visiting them.

Limestone in this area is fairly soft (for a rock) and may have been one reason people decided to settle here. Wood, plentiful on the canyon ridges overlooking the canyon, is another.

Kettle holes and ponds in the bedrock and nearby landscape may have been a source of water. Seeps and springs, like those found along Cliff Spring Trail (further south on Cape Royal Road), would have been another.

Excavated by Douglas W. Schwartz during the 1960's, this archaeological site is a sample of what used to be at least nine rooms, occupied from 1,100 to 1,150 CE.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 4, Walhalla Glades Pueblo. 1 ¾ minutes. The Walhalla Glades Pueblo is located across the road from entrance to the Walhalla Overlook pullout. Being mindful of traffic, move across the road to a flat gravel path lined with logs that leads about 400 feet (120 meters) north to an open area among the surrounding trees. Low, stacked limestone rock wall remnants outline the footprints of the half-dozen rooms of the pueblo. There is set of main rooms straight ahead, ranging in size from 10 to 15 feet (three to five meters) wide, and 10 to 20 feet (three to six meters) long. Note that this is an archeological site, and federal penalties can be imposed upon anyone who disturbs it. Touching or walking on the walls is not allowed, and removing any artifacts from this location is prohibited. Remains of adobe and beams in the rubble of these rooms indicated that the stone-walled rooms had roofs through which people entered by ladder. Near the north wall of the second room is a small, slab-lined fire pit. There are two smaller, separate rooms here to the west, and at the far end of the pueblo, a visible entryway connects the two large rooms built at the back. In the middle of the far wall of the last big room, stands a large, limestone slab, placed on-edge. Note to the west of the two back rooms of the main pueblo, two long rows of half-log benches face the pueblo under the trees. A second set of pueblo room remains stand to the east of the main pueblo, closer to the road. Consisting of one large and two smaller rooms, there is archaeological evidence these structures were built after the main structure burned down.

data.title: Walhalla Overlook
data.listingDescription: The North Rim developed area is CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. — From this overlook, you can see Echo Cliffs and the Painted Desert in the distance. The Little Colorado River Gorge can also be seen to the southeast. In the canyon below are Unkar Delta and the Colorado River, home to multiple archaeological sites and a significant location for Ancestral settlements.

images.altText: Steep cliffs are shadowed to the right as multicolored horizontal layers make up the Grand Canyon.
images.title: Walhalla Overlook
images.caption: View from Walhalla Overlook.

data.bodyText:
The North Rim developed area, including the lodge, visitor center and campground, are CLOSED until further notice because of extensive damage from the Dragon Bravo Wildfire. 

  • North Rim - Current Status and Closures

A splendid view, filled with history

From here, you can see Echo Cliffs and the Painted Desert in the distance. The Little Colorado River Gorge can also be seen to the southeast.

In the canyon below you are the Unkar Delta and Colorado River, home to multiple archaeological sites and a significant location for native people previously living in the area.

The drainages in the immediate vicinity below this overlook all feed into Unkar Creek, which drains into the Colorado River.

Across the road from here, take the short walk to Walhalla Glades Pueblo, an Ancestral Puebloan dwelling that is about 1000 years old.

History

In 1949, archeological student Douglas W. Schwartz visited Grand Canyon for the first time. Over 30 years of field work later, his surveys and excavations in the Unkar Delta, Walhalla Plateau and Bright Angel Pueblo areas revealed significant evidence of the Ancestral Puebloan people who lived on the Delta and along Unkar Creek. He also uncovered Walhalla Glades Pueblo, located a short walk from here on the path across the road.
data.audioDescription: A D Stop 3, Walhalla Overlook. 1 ½ minutes. Travelling south along Cape Royal Road, about six and a half miles (10 kilometers) past Roosevelt Point, a pullout to the left leads to a one-lane road beside the Walhalla Overlook, with parking on either side. Note a small wood and stone bench shelter and a wildlife-proof garbage can at the head (north end) of the lot. A five foot (two meter) wide asphalt sidewalk stretches over 500 feet (150 meters) south between the parking lane curb and a line of boulders at the edge of the canyon. About 150 feet (45 meters) along the sidewalk, a three-foot tall wayside panel mounted on an angled, metal reading rail tells the story of Puebloan farmers who once made the journey from river to rim on a routine basis. A description of this panel is included in the sub-script below. At this location, far below us, the Unkar Creek has carved a wide swath of rocky walls and sloping banks that open up to a panorama of the canyon floor and Unkar Delta. Fifteen miles (24 kilometers) in the distance, the walls of the South Rim rise steeply to a flat, desert plain. Much closer, off to the right, just beyond the point at Cape Royal, Vishnu Temple rises 7,500 feet (2,300 meters) into the air, topped with a pyramid-like limestone caprock. Sub-Script Living Delta to Rim Wayside Panel A panoramic color photograph of the canyon from Walhalla Overlook fills the face of the panel. Entitled “Living Delta to Rim,” words at the top of the panel read: From the North Rim, the Colorado River and the Unkar Delta below seem distant, yet ancestral Puebloan farmers 1,100 to 800 years ago made the journey from river to rim on a routine basis, spending summers on the rim and most of the remainder of the year within the canyon. For nearly five generations (about 100 years) farmers moved between Unkar Delta and Walhalla Glades, their summer home (across the road behind you). They successfully planted crops along the river, near water sources in side canyons, and on the North Rim. Corn, beans, and squash were their principle crops, but they also supplemented their diet with wild game, leafy plants, roots, nuts, and berries. The stone foundations of their dwellings, along with the artifacts left behind, tell stories of vibrant communities living in the harsh canyon environment. At the left, a white line from the Unkar Delta, far below in the center of the panel, connects to a circular inset photograph of rows of rocks arranged in neat squares and rectangles on the ground. A caption reads: Archaeologists can still piece together the stories of Unkar Delta’s ancient farming communities, even though floods have washed much of the evidence away. At the lower right, a green, circular Junior Ranger icon appears over an inset color photograph of more low, interconnected stone walls in a grove of trees. Text reads: Camp Walhalla Glades If you have been to summer camp, you probably traveled there by car or bus. Ancestral Puebloan children walked and climbed miles to their summer camp (across the road behind you), called Walhalla Glades. Find their winter home in the view and see if you can plot a route the children might have followed to camp.

data.title: Yaki Point
data.listingDescription: Yaki Point is the only scenic viewpoint on Desert View Drive that is not accessible with a private vehicle. It can be reached using the free Kaibab/Rim Route (Orange) shuttle, departing from Grand Canyon Visitor Center.

images.altText: Under a pale blue sky, the landscape of Grand Canyon is illuminated by the fading light of sunset.
images.title: Yaki Point, Looking East
images.caption: The fading light of sunset brings out deep, rich colors in Grand Canyon's rock layers.

data.bodyText:
Yaki Point is the only scenic viewpoint on Desert View Drive that is not accessible with a private vehicle. It can be reached using the free Kaibab/Rim Route (Orange) shuttle, departing from Grand Canyon Visitor Center.

Here the view of the canyon opens up to the east, with the Desert View Watchtower visible in the distance. A popular view for sunset and sunrise, the lack of private vehicles provides a bit more solitude than other canyon vistas.

data.title: Yaki Point Bus Stop - Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route
data.listingDescription: Yaki Point is the only viewpoint on Desert View Drive that is closed to private vehicles. It can only be visited on foot, bicycle, or by taking the free Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route shuttle, departing from the Visitor Center Transit Terminal. Yaki Point is often a relatively quiet place from which to enjoy sunset or sunrise, with expansive views both to the east and west. Vault toilets are located here. Visit the link for the current schedule.

images.altText: a green and white bus with passengers at a bus stop with a vast canyon landscape in the distance.
images.title: Kaibab (Orange) Route bus at Yaki Point

data.bodyText:
Nearby:

Yaki Point is the only viewpoint on Desert View Drive that is closed to private vehicles. It can be only be reached by taking the free eastbound Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route shuttle, departing from the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal.

December 1, 2025, through February 28, 2026

Route Information

The Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route is a shuttle bus loop that takes approximately 50 minutes to ride the entire route and return to the same location. At the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal, there are separate stops for the eastbound and westbound shuttles. Additional bus stops are at the following locations:

data.title: Yavapai Geology Museum
data.listingDescription: One of the best vantage points for an overview of Grand Canyon geology, the museum on the very edge of the canyon rim at Yavapai Point. Inside is a bookstore and museum shop, large picture windows for canyon views, and a variety of geology exhibits. Restrooms are in a separate building adjacent to the parking lot. The shuttle bus stop is also on the parking lot. ► Follow the link for hours of operation

images.altText: A rustic stone building with large windows on the edge of a cliff overlooking a canyon.
images.title: Yavapai Museum of Geology
images.caption: Perched on the rim, Yavapai Geology Museum helps one gain an understanding of how the canyon formed.

data.bodyText:
Hours of Operation

Open Daily: 8 am to 6 pm

Perched right on the very edge of the canyon rim at Yavapai Point, Yavapai Geology Museum offers one of the best vantage points for an overview of Grand Canyon geology.

Parking is available. It is also possible to ride the Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route shuttle from the Visitor Center, or walk the Canyon Rim Trail from the Visitor Center/Mather Point, a distance of 0.7 miles (1.1 km).

The Museum Features:

  • Bookstore and Museum Shop
  • Large Picture Windows for viewing the canyon
  • Exhibits (about the geology of Grand Canyon)
  • Public Restrooms in a separate building by the parking lot
  • Shuttle Bus Stop for transport to and from the Visitor Center

A 30-Minute Geology Program is Presented Daily

(Beginning Sunday, December 7) Time: 1:30 - 2:00 pm daily - 30-minutes
Meet the ranger in front of the Museum. Learn how this immense canyon formed and the science behind the landscape. The program is accessible. 

Yavapai Geology Museum was originally built in 1928 and retains much of its historic character.

Annotated displays at the base of the panoramic windows show you where to look to see each group of rocks. A large, sculpted relief map in the center of the room provides a way to get acquainted with the shape of the canyon and where its various landmarks are relative to one another.

You can walk between rock column models of the North and South Rims, learn the names of the various rock layers, discover information about the geologic history recorded in the rocks, and visualize the carving of the modern landscape.

The Grand Canyon Conservancy operates a Park Store in the building which sells books, souvenirs, and gifts. Restrooms and a water fountain are located in a separate building adjacent to the parking lot.

The Trail of Time, the world's largest outdoor geoscience exhibit, starts just 650 feet (198 m) to the west of the museum along the Rim Trail.
data.audioDescription: Situated on prominent Yavapai Point, Yavapai Geology Museum is an irregularly-shaped one-story building, approximately 40-feet (12 m) deep by 65-feet (20 m) wide, with a semi-circular observation enclosed terrace on the north side overlooking the canyon. The structure's exterior walls and foundation are made of uniformly-sized, native Kaibab Formation boulders with buttressed corners which give the building a rich variation in form, texture, and line. The building has a low, flat asphalt roof, timber beams, and protruding wood rafters. Other rustic characteristics include small window openings, and timber doors. The splayed courses of the building merge into the surrounding curbing and paving stones. Inside, a vast 3,000 square foot (900 square meter) room houses a wide variety of geology exhibits that showcase the canyon's history, including a scale model of Grand Canyon, samples of its geologic layers, plant and animal fossils, specimens of modern flora and fauna common to the region, and maps and charts for public use. The entire north wall is covered with a series of five 10-foot (3 m) wide by five-foot (1.5 m) tall windows with sweeping views of the North Rim, the inner canyon, and the Colorado River far below. A variety of interpretive displays explain the deposition of the canyon's strata, the uplift of the Colorado Plateau, and the role of the Colorado River in carving Grand Canyon over time. These exhibits are augmented by daily interpretive talks conducted by National Park Service park rangers about Grand Canyon's geologic history. There is a small Grand Canyon Conservancy Park Store on the opposite side of the room from the windows at the left. While there are no restrooms inside the museum, they are available down a short paved trail at the parking lot.
data.passportStampLocationDescription: Yavapai Geology Museum has its own unique, official, dated passport cancellation stamp which reads "Yavapai Geology Museum" at the bottom. As the museum contains a park bookstore, it also has a special Grand Canyon Conservancy stamp featuring a bighorn sheep and the building's original name, "Yavapai Observation Station".

data.title: Yavapai Geology Museum Bus Stop - Kaibab Rim (Orange) Route
data.listingDescription: Located on the northeast end of the parking lot below Yavapai Geology Museum, this shuttle stop is for passengers arriving from, or returning to the Visitor Center. The small restroom building is alongside this parking lot. The level footpath behind the shuttle stop goes to the outdoor amphitheater on the rim. Follow the path up the hill to Yavapai Geology Museum and Yavapai Point. The paved Canyon Rim Trail continues both east and west from here. Visit the link for schedule

images.altText: White and green shuttle bus is stopped at a sign, waiting for visitors to board.
images.title: Yavapai Geology Museum Orange Route Stop
images.caption: Boarding the shuttle bus at this stop will return you directly to the visitor center

data.bodyText:
Nearby:

  • Public Restrooms
  • Yavapai Point 
  • Geology Museum and Museum Store 
  • Amphitheater
  • Canyon Rim Trail and Trail of Time Outdoor Exhibit 


Located at the northeast end of the parking lot below Yavapai Geology Museum, this shuttle bus stop is for visitors arriving from — and returning to — Grand Canyon Visitor Center.

Public restrooms are located in a small building along the north side of the parking lot. 

To attend a ranger program at the amphitheater, follow the level footpath directly behind the shuttle stop to the amphitheater on the edge of Grand Canyon

Walking the uphill path ifrom the bus stop leads to Yavapai Geology Museum, and Yavapai Point. The location of Yavapai Point was selected by a team of geologists for observing and understanding Grand Canyon geology. 

From the museum, it is a 0.7 mile (1.1 km) walk east, to Mather Point and the Visitor Center along the paved, and wheelchair accessible, Canyon Rim Trail. 

Walking west along the Canyon Rim Trail will take you to the Village Historic District in 1.4 miles (2.3 km). This section of the trail, is called the Trail of Time, it is a geologic timeline with a series of outdoor exhibits that explain how Grand Canyon formed.

Kaibab (Orange) Route - Winter Schedule

December 1, 2025, through February 28, 2026
50 minutes round trip (without getting off the bus)

First bus is at 8:00 am — last bus is at 7:00 pm
► Be at a bus stop no later than 6:45 pm

  • Every 20 minutes: 8:00 am to 10:30 am
  • Every 15 minutes: 10:30am to 3:30 pm
  • Every 20 minutes: 3:30 pm to 7:00 pm

The Kaibab/Rim (Orange) Route is a shuttle bus loop that takes approximately 50 minutes to ride the entire route and return to the same location. At the Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal, there are separate stops for the eastbound and westbound shuttles. Additional bus stops are at the following locations:
 

Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal (westbound)

  • Mather Point
  • Yavapai Geology Museum
     

Visitor Center Shuttle Bus Terminal (eastbound)

  • South Kaibab Trailhead
  • Yaki Point
  • Pipe Creek Vista

Shuttle Bus Rules

  • No pets allowed on shuttle buses. Service dogs are permitted (as defined by the Americans With Disabilities Act).
  • No eating or open drink containers.

  • Shuttle buses are equipped with ramps and space to carry passengers in wheelchairs. Please note that wheelchairs larger than 30 inches wide by 48 inches long (76 cm x 122 cm) cannot be accommodated on shuttle buses, and most motorized scooters will not fit.

  • Collapse strollers before entering the shuttle bus. No oversized or jogging strollers. Remove baby-back carriers when seated.

  • Shuttle buses can accommodate two or three bicycles, but not tag alongs, baby trailers, or children's bicycles with wheels less than 16 inches (41 cm). Riders must load and unload their bicycles from the front-facing rack.

  • Shuttle buses only stop at designated bus stops.

data.title: Yavapai Lodge
data.listingDescription: Located in Market Plaza, the South Rim's business center, the lodge has a cafeteria style restaurant, coffee shop/cafe, gift shop and an outdoor patio tavern with a food menu. Pet friendly rooms are available. it's a short walk across the parking lot to Canyon Village Market (General Store and Deli), and the U.S. Post Office. From the lodge, it averages around a one mile (1.6 km) walk, along paved footpaths, to the edge of the canyon. ► Follow the link for hours of operation.

images.altText: several people stand by the entrance to a modern lodge with a gabled roof
images.title: Entrance to Yavapai Lodge Lobby
images.caption: Find lodging, food, a coffee bar, and televisions at Yavapai Lodge in Market Plaza

data.bodyText:
Proximity to Market Plaza, the South Rim's business center, is one of the features of Yavapai Lodge. From the lodge, it is a short walk across the plaza to Canyon Village Market (the General Store), the US Post Office, and 8 EV charging stations near the lodge. Details >

From the lodge, it averages around a one mile (1.6 km) walk, along paved footpaths, to the edge of Grand Canyon. Ask at the front desk for directions.

Hours of operation updated December 5, 2024.

Dining

  • Yavapai Lodge Restaurant 
    Breakfast: 7 am to 10 am - daily
    Dinner: 5 pm to 8 pm - daily
    Located inside, just past the lobby, the restaurant provides family-friendly, casual, sit-down dining options. (Breakfast and dinner only). 
 
  • Yavapai Tavern, outdoor patio - bar with a food menu.
    11:00 am to 9:00 pm - daily
    Enjoy a classic full bar at Yavapai Tavern, featuring Arizona craft beer and a great selection of wine. The Tavern offers a southwestern-inspired food menu, including flatbread pizzas, burgers, and street tacos. Enjoy a signature cocktail by the fire in the Tavern's spacious outdoor dining area.
 
  • Coffee Shop and Cafe:
    7 am to 2 pm 
    Located in the main lodge building; stop by for a cup of coffee in the morning or to grab a quick bite before you head out on a hike.
 
  • Gift shop: 
    8 am to 8 pm 
     

Accommodations

Yavapai Lodge East

Rooms in Yavapai East are located in six separate two-story buildings. These are their newest guestrooms and feature modern amenities, including air conditioning. 

A number of accessible rooms are available in Yavapai East for guests with mobility needs, including some with roll-in showers. To view the current accessible rooms, check the "ADA/Accessible Rooms" box in the online reservations application. Yavapai East is NOT pet-friendly, however, they do have pet-friendly rooms available at Yavapai West.

  • In front of Yavapai Lodge East, Building 1, three universal and three Tesla electric vehicle chargers are available to the public, and free of charge . Details > 

Yavapai Lodge West

Rooms in Yavapai West are located in ten single-story Mid-Century Modern buildings from the heyday of Route 66. These rooms also have air conditioning, 

A number of pet-friendly rooms are available in Yavapai West for guests traveling with their four-legged friends. There is an additional $25 pet fee per day, and each room can have up to two pets. We offer a Pets in the Park Package which includes: loaner kennel, waste bags located in receptacles outside of building 9, loaner food/water dishes, and treat in the room. The package will also include the pet fee.

Lodging and Contact Information

For day-of check-in and availability information for Yavapai Lodge, check with staff directly at the Yavapai Lodge lobby desk.

Visit the lodge website here: Yavapai Lodge - Grand Canyon (visitgrandcanyon.com)

For advance reservations, which are recommended for all holidays and throughout the summer, visit the website or call toll-free within the US 877-404-4611. For those outside the US call 801-449-4139.

data.title: Yavapai Point Amphitheater
data.listingDescription: Just a short walk east of Yavapai Geology Museum, Yavapai Point Amphitheater is a great place to take a photo, enjoy a park ranger program, and relax. If you continue walking east on the blacktop footpath along the rim of the canyon, it is a 0.7 mile (1.1 km) walk to Mather Point and the Visitor Center, where parking lots 1-4 are located. (Note: the amphitheater benches are being renovated and will be installed during spring 2025).

images.altText: Visitors sit on stone and wooden benches overlooking the Grand Canyon, surrounded by stout trees.
images.title: Yavapai Point Amphitheater
images.caption: The Yavapai Point Amphitheater, along the Rim Trail, offers sweeping views of the Grand Canyon.

data.bodyText:
Note: the amphitheater benches are being renovated and should be installed during spring 2025. It is still possible to walk up to the railing for exceptional views of the canyon during sunrise and sunset.

Just a short walk east of Yavapai Geology Museum, Yavapai Point Amphitheater is a great place to take a photo, enjoy a park ranger program, and relax. Walk up to the railing and check out the rock samples embedded in the posts. Touch a piece of Vishnu Schist, dating back nearly 1.8 billion years ago!

From the amphitheater, follow the blacktop footpath east, along the rim of the canyon, for 0.7 mile (1.1 km) to Mather Point and the Visitor Center, with parking lots 1-4.

During warmer months, Park Ranger programs about geology are held here. Inquire at the Yavapai Geology Museum for more information and times.
data.audioDescription: The Yavapai Amphitheater is located along the Rim Trail about 300 feet (90 m) east of the Yavapai Geology Museum. A 100-foot (30 m) wide, roughly semi-circular shaded seating area with a few juniper trees faces the canyon behind a four-foot (1.2 m) tall metal railing and stone pillar fence at the edge. Multiple wood log and terraced stone benches are spread out across a 100-foot (30 m) wide rocky, uneven and sloping ground of the open-air amphitheater. Two uneven stone steps lead down into the amphitheater from the trail at the west. Fifty-feet (15 m) farther east along the trail, a paved asphalt ramp leads north down a slight incline into the theater. Be mindful of a small step as you move off the path onto the dirt. As at the Yavapai Geology Museum, this location offers sweeping views of the North Rim, the inner canyon, and the Colorado River far below.
